Package emissary.test.util

Class ComplexUnicodeSamples

  • java.lang.Object
    • emissary.test.util.ComplexUnicodeSamples
  • public final class ComplexUnicodeSamples
extends Object
    A class that provides some tricky samples. These samples can be used in testing to make sure our code and the 3rd party libraries we choose can handle unusual cases.

    Each example contains detailed explanation and links to useful reference materials.

    • Method Detail

      • getFacePalmingMaleControlSkintone

        public static String getFacePalmingMaleControlSkintone()
        Returns a string that contains one graphical unit (in this case an emoji) that consists of 5 Unicode scalar values. The user-perceived string would be one facepalming emoji. A user would expect hit the arrow key once to traverse the cursor across this one emoji on the screen. The length of the UTF-8 encoded byte array is 17 bytes. One emoji, 17 UTF8 bytes.

        SCALAR 1: First, there’s a base character that means a person face palming.

        SCALAR 2: By default, the person would have a cartoonish yellow color. The next character is an emoji skintone modifier the changes the color of the person’s skin (and, in practice, also the color of the person’s hair).

        SCALAR 3 and 4: By default, the gender of the person is undefined, and e.g. Apple defaults to what they consider a male appearance and e.g. Google defaults to what they consider a female appearance. The next two scalar values pick a male-typical appearance specifically regardless of font and vendor. Instead of being an emoji-specific modifier like the skin tone, the gender specification uses an emoji-predating gender symbol (MALE SIGN) explicitly ligated using the ZERO WIDTH JOINER with the (skin-toned) face-palming person. (Whether it is a good or a bad idea that the skin tone and gender specifications use different mechanisms is out of the scope of this post.)

        SCALAR 5: Finally, VARIATION SELECTOR-16 makes it explicit that we want a multicolor emoji rendering instead of a monochrome dingbat rendering.

        Returns:
        the Java string containing this one facepalming dude emoji with a not-yellow skin tone.
        See Also:
        ComplexUnicodeSamplesTest.demonstrateMetadataAboutFacePalmDude(), https://hsivonen.fi/string-length/

      • getXmlSamples

        public static Map<String,​String> getXmlSamples()
        This map is useful for testing that our code and any 3rd party XML library we are using is handling unicode within XML correctly.
        Returns:
        A map of strings where the key is the XML node containing an XML-escaped surrogate pair unicode value and the value is is the properly extracted java string value with un-escaped unicode strings.
        See Also:
        https://github.com/FasterXML/woodstox/pull/174/files

      • countGraphemesUsingJavaBuiltInBreakIterator

        public static int countGraphemesUsingJavaBuiltInBreakIterator​(String text)
        This will not work properly in versions of java earlier than Java 20.

        Once we get to Java 20, this method should work properly.

        Character boundary analysis allows users to interact with characters as they expect to, for example, when moving the cursor through a text string. Character boundary analysis provides correct navigation through character strings, regardless of how the character is stored. The boundaries returned may be those of supplementary characters, combining character sequences, or ligature clusters. For example, an accented character might be stored as a base character and a diacritical mark. What users consider to be a character can differ between languages.

        Parameters:
        text - - the string to analyze.
        Returns:
        the count of user-perceived graphemes as based on the character break iterator. In versions of java earlier than Java 20, this will not function as expected.
        See Also:
        https://horstmann.com/unblog/2023-10-03/index.html - Scroll to the section titled "Just Use Strings"

      • countGraphemesUsingIcu4J

        public static int countGraphemesUsingIcu4J​(String text)
        Using the industry-standard ICU4J library provided by IBM.

        NOTE: Updating the version of this library might change which unicode database is referenced for these calculations. We should strive to keep this library as up-to-date as possible in both test and production source code.

        Parameters:
        text - the string to analyze
        Returns:
        a count of how many user-perceived glyphs/graphemes are present in the string. If you placed a cursor diretly to the left (or right for right-to-left string), and pressed the arrow key to traverse the string, how many times would you need to press the arrow key to traverse to the right-most end of the string (or leftmost for R-to-L strings).
